title: I tried to prove I'm not AI

But it includes a whole bunch of

cryptographically sealed
metadata how do you make

okay metadata is just the information

problem is traditional metadata can be

just use a metadata Editor to make it

so how can I prove that my photo is
legit one way would be to put it inside
a kind of digital security envelope and
seal it with a signature from the camera
app so other people could verify that it
came from a trusted source and there'd
also be a little reference photo on the
envelope so that you could compare it to
the image itself and look for changes
that's what ctpa is building it's an
open source system so that any tool that
makes images would also be able to make
these envelopes and sign them the thing
that's opening the envelope is like
Instagram or like ideally the
infrastructure can be built in across
everywhere that we see media so that
you'd see this icon and be able to get
more information about the media that
we're being served so how do you make a
seal that can't be faked you use
cryptography which is the science of
hiding and verifying information let's
begin with that little reference image
on our metaphorical envelope the
original photo is stored as binary data
a series of ones and zeros that make up
every line of metadata and every pixel
in the photo true pick chops and
scrambles that data down to a 64 digigit
code called a hash using a well-known
hashing algorithm to give you a sense of
what that looks like take a chunk of the
photo data and just slide the bits to
the right by two and you get this if you
slide them to the right by nine it looks
like this then you can merge those by
taking a zero if they show the same
number in a position and a one if they
have different numbers now you have this
new sequence quence do that with another
chunk of the photo and you get this then
you can combine those in the same way
the hashing algorithm does that sort of
thing across all the data to an absurd
degree until it has cooked it down to a
little 64 digigit hash and it can do
this for any digital file no matter the
size if anything in that file changes
the hash isn't just a little different
it's completely different so in our
metaphor the hash is that small
reference photo on the envelope it's a
way for trck to say this is what the
photo looked like when it was taken to
check if something has been altered
anyone can take the full photo and
recompute the hash because that
algorithm is available to anyone and if

the hashes won't match so the hash lets
